question: Mega Menu Add-on
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 2 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu Add-on allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can select the "Edit" option to make changes to the menu.

The menu settings can be customized in the Theme page by adding custom CSS. Users can hide certain elements using CSS selectors and modify the position of the menu using CSS properties like "position" and "display".

Once the theme is saved, users can go to the configuration page via the URL provided to configure the Mega Menu Add-On. The configuration page allows users to customize various aspects of the menu, such as the behavior, effects, speed, and styling of the menu.

Users can also configure visibility rules for the menu items. Visibility rules allow users to control which menu items are displayed based on certain conditions, such as user profile field values. Users can create and manage visibility rules to customize the menu based on different user attributes.

The Mega Menu Add-on also provides options for exporting and importing the configuration settings. Users can export the current settings to use them in another environment or instance. This feature can also be used as a backup for previous configurations.

The installation process for the Mega Menu Add-on involves creating user groups for admins and editors, setting system properties, and uploading the add-on package. The add-on can be installed on both cloud and hosted/on-prem Jive instances. Detailed installation instructions are provided in the document.

In terms of updates and fixes, the release notes mention various improvements and bug fixes for the Advanced Navigation Add-on (former Mega Menu Add-On). The latest version is 1.2.19, and it addresses issues related to menu behavior, translations, and user interface display.

In the comments section, there are discussions about issues with the menu position in mobile view, logo visibility for external users, and font size customization for descriptions. The support team suggests raising support tickets for specific issues and mentions that future releases may address these concerns.

Overall, the Mega Menu Add-on provides a comprehensive solution for creating and configuring a mega menu in Jive. Users have control over various settings and can customize the menu based on their specific requirements.

The Mega Menu Add-On allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can edit the menu by selecting the "Edit" option on the top left. The Mega Menu settings will then be displayed in an editable mode.

The configuration of the Mega Menu involves several settings and elements. The "General Settings" include options such as the behavior of the dropdown panel, the speed of panel rendering, and the logo and URL settings. Users can also configure the position and stickiness of the Mega Menu.

The Mega Menu can be customized further by adding visibility rules. These rules allow users to control the visibility of menu items based on profile field values. Users can create and manage visibility rules, specifying the field name, field value, and condition for each rule.

Menu settings include the creation of menu items, translation for different languages, and the creation of dropdown menus. Users can add menu items with titles, target URLs, icons, and layout options. They can also create dropdown menus in either a vertical tab style or a grid style, with the ability to add columns and rows.

Once the Mega Menu is configured, users can save the settings and activate the menu. The configuration can also be exported and imported to use the same settings in another environment or instance.

The Mega Menu Add-On also provides installation instructions for both cloud Jive instances and hosted/on-prem Jive instances. The installation process involves creating user groups, setting system properties, and uploading and configuring the Mega Menu Add-On.

In terms of updates and fixes, the Advanced Navigation Add-on (former Mega Menu Add-On) has had several releases with improvements and bug fixes. The latest version is 1.2.19, which includes fixes for issues such as disappearing menus, translation rules not applying, and scrolling issues.

In summary, the Mega Menu Add-On allows users to create and configure a customizable mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements, including dropdown menus, visibility rules, and translation for different languages. The add-on provides a user-friendly interface for managing and editing the menu settings.

question: How to set kubectl to access MAKO?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the Maven binary from the Maven website. You can find the download link [here](http://maven.apache.org/download.html).
2. Unpack the binary on your system. If you are using a Mac, explode the zip file to /usr/local. If you are using Windows, extract the downloaded Maven zip file to the root of the C: drive, which will create a maven-2.2.1 folder.
3. Set your environment path. If you are using a Mac, add a M2_HOME environment variable to your ~/.bash_profile and point it to your download. For example:
\`\`\`
export M2_HOME=/usr/local/apache-maven-2.2.1
\`\`\`
Also, add the $M2_HOME/bin directory to your path, before /usr/bin.
If you are using Windows, adjust the System Path Variable by appending a semi-colon and the location of the maven\bin directory. For example:
\`\`\`
C:\maven-2.2.1\bin
\`\`\`
4. Test your installation by running the command \`mvn --version\`. You should see the Apache Maven version and Java version information.

Please note that the provided information is based on the extracted parts of a long document and may not cover all possible scenarios. It is always recommended to refer to the official documentation or seek assistance from the relevant support channels for specific instructions related to your environment.
search_phrase: how to set up kubectl to access MAKO
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set up kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the kubectl binary from the official Kubernetes website. You can find the download link [here](http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/prereqs/).

2. Once you have downloaded the binary, you need to make it executable. You can do this by running the following command in your terminal:

\`\`\`
chmod +x kubectl
\`\`\`

3. Next, you need to move the kubectl binary to a directory that is in your system's PATH. This will allow you to run kubectl from anywhere in your terminal. You can do this by running the following command:

\`\`\`
sudo mv kubectl /usr/local/bin/
\`\`\`

4. Now that kubectl is installed, you need to configure it to access MAKO. To do this, you will need the necessary credentials and configuration files from the MAKO administrator. Once you have these files, you can place them in the appropriate directory on your system.

5. The exact location of the configuration files may vary depending on your operating system and setup. However, a common location is \`~/.kube/config\`. You can place the configuration files in this directory by running the following command:

\`\`\`
mv /path/to/config/files ~/.kube/config
\`\`\`

6. Finally, you can test your kubectl setup by running the following command:

\`\`\`
kubectl get pods
\`\`\`

If everything is set up correctly, you should see a list of pods running in your MAKO cluster.

Please note that these instructions are general and may need to be adapted to your specific setup. It is always recommended to consult the official documentation or seek assistance from the MAKO administrator for detailed instructions on setting up kubectl to access MAKO.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers are very similar in terms of the steps provided to set up kubectl to access MAKO. The only difference is the source of the binaries and the location of the configuration files, which are specific to the user's operating system and setup.

question: What is jive?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
Jive is a social collaboration tool for business that allows people from different functional areas to connect, share ideas, and collaborate. It breaks down walls between departments and facilitates innovation and problem-solving. Jive provides a platform for people to find information, work on projects, and write documents together. It also allows for the creation of communities where niche information can be shared and tribal knowledge can be broken down. Jive enables people to connect, interact, and work with others across the office, street, or country. It is a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools with seamless functionality, increasing effectiveness and efficiency. Jive is often described as a cross between a social network and enterprise tools, providing a better way to work and collaborate.

question: what features has Jive released in the last 12 months?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive has released several features in the last 12 months. Some of the key features released in the last 12 months include:

1. Engagement Analytics: Jive 9 introduced Engagement Analytics, which provides detailed insights into user interactions and community participation. Community managers can track user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community.

2. Jive Daily: Jive Daily is a mobile app for Jive-n users that allows employees to stay connected to their company intranet or employee community. It provides features such as inbox notifications, news feed and activity streams, search functionality, content viewing and sharing, and the ability to create discussions, questions, status updates, messages, and videos.

3. Content Management: Jive introduced bulk content management, which allows users to quickly and easily modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can also copy documents, discussions, or blog posts as templates for others to use.

4. New Tiles: Jive made several improvements to tiles and introduced new tiles in Jive 9. These new tiles provide enhanced functionality and customization options for users.

5. Spotlight Search: Jive introduced a redesigned Spotlight Search feature that allows users to quickly find items using keywords. The search automatically includes wildcards as users type parts of words and provides history and suggestions tabs for easy access to frequently viewed items.

6. Support Center: Jive introduced the Support Center, which provides a streamlined experience for customers or employees to find answers and contribute knowledge. The Support Center helps in case deflection, reducing costs, and increasing customer satisfaction.

7. Jive for Lync/Skype for Business: Jive introduced an add-on that allows users to collaborate in real-time using Lync or Skype for Business without leaving the Jive community.

These are just a few of the features that Jive has released in the last 12 months. For a complete list of features and more detailed information, it is recommended to refer to the official Jive documentation or contact Jive support.

Jive has released several new features in the last 12 months. Here are some of the key features:

1. Engagement Analytics: Jive 9 introduces Engagement Analytics, which provides detailed insights into user interactions that drive community participation and performance. Community managers can analyze user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community.

2. Jive Daily: Jive Daily is now a mobile app for Jive-n users. It allows employees to stay connected to the Jive-n company intranet or employee community from anywhere. Users can read company news, follow personalized activity streams, create and share content, and more.

3. Content Management: Jive 9 introduces bulk content management, allowing users to quickly modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can add categories and tags, move or delete content, and set outcomes in bulk. Additionally, Jive now has a "Copy Document" action that allows users to clone the title, body, and publishing information of a document into a new piece of content.

4. New Tiles: Jive 9 includes several new tiles, including Forms, which allows users to create forms for community users, and Jive Albums, which enables the creation of photo galleries in Jive.

5. News: The Winter 2015 release introduces the News feature, which allows community managers to choose what activity users should automatically follow. It also includes other minor features such as the Subscribers Toggle in Impact Metrics and new Community Manager Reports.

6. Promoted Results: Jive now supports Promoted Results, which allows community managers to create rulesets to ensure that specific keywords always return specific content results, even if the keyword does not occur in the content.

These are just a few of the latest features released by Jive in the last 12 months. For more information, you can refer to the full release notes and documentation provided by Jive.

question: What does expires_in for Jive OAuth 2 mean ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter for Jive OAuth 2 refers to the duration of time in seconds for which an access token is valid. After this duration, the access token will expire and can no longer be used to authenticate API requests. The expiration time is specified in the response when obtaining an access token. The default expiration time for an access token in Jive is 48 hours (172,800 seconds). Once the access token expires, you will need to use the refresh token to obtain a new access token. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and can be used to request a new access token once the current one expires. It is important to note that the expiration time for access and refresh tokens can be configured and customized in Jive's settings.
search_phrase: meaning of expires_in in Jive OAuth 2
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter in Jive OAuth 2 refers to the duration of time for which an access token is valid. It specifies the number of seconds until the access token expires. Once the access token expires, it can no longer be used to authenticate API requests.

In Jive, the default expiration duration for an access token is 48 hours from the time of issuance. After this period, any request made with an expired access token will result in a 401 response code. However, it is important to note that the expiration duration of access tokens can be customized by setting the system property \`jive.oauth.acess_token.ttl_hours\` to a different value. This allows administrators to control the lifespan of access tokens based on their specific requirements.

It is worth mentioning that Jive also supports refresh tokens, which can be used to obtain a new access token without having to go through the full OAuth process again. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and can be used to request a new access token once the current one expires. This allows for seamless authentication without requiring the user to reauthenticate every time the access token expires.

In summary, the \`expires_in\` parameter in Jive OAuth 2 specifies the duration of time for which an access token is valid. The default expiration duration is 48 hours, but it can be customized by setting the appropriate system property. Refresh tokens can be used to obtain new access tokens without reauthentication.

question: What does expires_in for jive oauth api indicate?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` field in the Jive OAuth API indicates the duration of validity for an access token. It specifies the number of seconds until the access token expires. Once the access token expires, it can no longer be used to authenticate API requests. The default expiration time for an access token in Jive is 48 hours. After the expiration time, a new access token needs to be obtained using the refresh token. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and is used to request a new access token once the current one expires.

To revoke tokens in Jive, you can use the OAuth Client Management feature. This feature allows you to revoke access to specific applications that were previously granted access. Revoking access will invalidate both the access token and the refresh token, requiring the user to grant access again using the Authorization Code Grant method. You can revoke access through the Jive UI by going to "Manage Add-ons" > "Apps Management" and revoking access to specific applications. Alternatively, you can revoke access through a REST API call using the Jive REST API's Authorization entity.

It is not possible to obtain a non-expiring token in Jive OAuth. The expiration duration of access and refresh tokens can be specified by the administrator of the community through a system property. By setting the expiration duration to several years, the tokens can be effectively made non-expiring. In the upcoming cloud release of Jive, this setting can be configured on a per-addon (client) basis in the advanced UI settings of that addon.

In summary, the \`expires_in\` field in the Jive OAuth API indicates the duration of validity for an access token. The default expiration time for an access token is 48 hours, and the refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years. Tokens can be revoked through the OAuth Client Management feature in the Jive UI or through a REST API call. It is not possible to obtain a non-expiring token, but the expiration duration can be configured by the community administrator.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The Jive OAuth2 implementation allows for the revocation of tokens and setting expiration date/time intervals for access and refresh tokens. Tokens can be revoked via the OAuth Client Management UI or through a REST API call. The expiration duration of access and refresh tokens can be specified through a system property, and in the upcoming cloud release of Jive, this setting can be configured on a per-addon (client) basis in the advanced UI settings of that addon.

Unfortunately, it is not possible to obtain a non-expiring token in Jive's OAuth2 implementation. However, if you are the administrator of the community, you can specify a long expiration duration for access and refresh tokens, effectively making them non-expiring. This can be done by setting a system property to a duration of several years.

To obtain a new access token using a refresh token, you can make a POST request to YOUR-JIVE-URL/oauth2/token with the refresh_token, grant_type, client_id, and client_secret as parameters. This will give you a brand new access token.

When making REST API calls, you can use the access token in the Authorization header as "Bearer ". The access token is valid for 48 hours by default, and a request made with an expired access token will result in a 401 response code. To request a new access token using a refresh token, you can use the refresh token, client ID, and client secret in a POST request to YOUR-JIVE-URL/oauth2/token with the grant_type set to refresh_token.

In terms of token expiration settings, the default expiration duration for access tokens is 48 hours, and the default expiration duration for refresh tokens is 10 years. These settings can be changed in the advanced settings of the OAuth Client Management UI.

To revoke permissions granted to an application, you can use the App Management UI to revoke access to specific applications. This will revoke both the access and refresh tokens, requiring the user to grant access again using the Authorization Code Grant method. Alternatively, you can revoke access through a REST API call using the Jive REST API's Authorization entity.

It is possible to use OAuth tokens with v3 API authentication in Jive. Both HTTP Basic Authentication and OAuth token-based authentication can be successfully used with the v3 API.

Regarding the use of Jive cloud instance as the directory and authentication provider for clients, it is possible to authenticate clients in Jive and allow them to access extranet and other web sites using the same credentials. However, the specific approach and implementation details may vary depending on the requirements and setup of the Jive instance.

In summary, Jive's OAuth2 implementation allows for token revocation, setting expiration durations for tokens, obtaining new access tokens using refresh tokens, and using OAuth tokens with v3 API authentication. It is not possible to obtain a non-expiring token, but the expiration duration can be set to a long duration. The OAuth Client Management UI and REST API can be used for token management and revocation.

question: What does expires_in for Jive OAuth 2 mean ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter for Jive OAuth 2 refers to the duration of time in seconds for which an access token is valid. After this duration, the access token will expire and can no longer be used to authenticate API requests. The expiration time is specified in the response when obtaining an access token. For example, the response may include an \`expires_in\` value of 172799 seconds, which corresponds to approximately 48 hours.

When an access token expires, it is necessary to use the refresh token to obtain a new access token. The refresh token has a longer lifespan, typically 10 years, and can be used to request a new access token once the current one expires. This process allows for continuous authentication without requiring the user to re-enter their credentials.

It is important to note that the expiration duration of access and refresh tokens can be configured in Jive. The default expiration for access tokens is 48 hours, while refresh tokens have a default lifespan of 10 years. However, these settings can be adjusted based on the specific requirements of the application or system. The expiration settings can be modified through the Jive UI in the advanced settings of the OAuth client management section.

In summary, the \`expires_in\` parameter for Jive OAuth 2 indicates the duration in seconds for which an access token is valid. After this duration, the access token will expire and can no longer be used for authentication. The refresh token can be used to obtain a new access token once the current one expires, allowing for continuous authentication without requiring the user to re-enter their credentials. The expiration duration of access and refresh tokens can be configured in Jive to meet the specific requirements of the application or system.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter in Jive OAuth 2 refers to the expiration time of an access token. By default, the access token is valid for 48 hours from issuance. After the expiration time, if you attempt to use the access token, you will receive a 401 response code indicating that the token has expired.

To obtain a new access token, you can use the refresh token provided by the Jive server. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and is used to request a new access token once the current one expires. You can make a POST request to the \`/oauth2/token\` endpoint with the following parameters:

\`\`\`
refresh_token = [your refresh token]
grant_type = refresh_token
client_id = [your client id]
client_secret = [your client secret]
\`\`\`

This will give you a brand new access token that you can use to make REST API calls.

It is important to note that it is not possible to get a non-expiring token in Jive OAuth 2. The expiration time is set to ensure security and prevent unauthorized access. However, as an administrator of the community, you can specify the expiration duration of access and refresh tokens through a system property. By setting it to be several years long, you can effectively make the tokens appear non-expiring. In the upcoming cloud release of Jive, this setting can be configured on a per-addon (client) basis in the advanced UI settings of that addon.

Additionally, you can revoke tokens in Jive through the UI or by performing a REST API call. In the UI, you can go to "Manage Add-ons" and revoke access to specific applications. This will revoke both the access and refresh tokens, requiring the user to grant access again using the Authorization Code Grant method. Alternatively, you can use the Jive REST API to retrieve a list of authorizations given by a person and then delete specific grants to revoke access.

In summary, the \`expires_in\` parameter in Jive OAuth 2 refers to the expiration time of an access token. The default expiration time is 48 hours, and you can obtain a new access token using the refresh token. It is not possible to get a non-expiring token, but you can set the expiration duration of tokens through system properties and revoke tokens through the UI or REST API.

question: why should I use jive ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 6 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 14 November, 2018, here is the answer:
Jive is a business collaboration tool that offers several advantages over traditional email communication. It allows for open and collaborative conversations, breaking down the limitations of email where only selected individuals are included in the conversation. With Jive, people can connect, share ideas, and collaborate across different functional areas, fostering innovation and speeding up problem-solving. Jive also provides a centralized and searchable repository for discussions and knowledge sharing, making it easier to access and retrieve information. Additionally, Jive offers users the choice to opt-in to specific activity feeds, reducing the clutter of irrelevant information that often comes with email.

One of the common misconceptions about Jive is that it is just another task to add to an already busy workload. However, Jive is not an additional burden but rather an alternative communication tool to traditional email. While email may be the most frequently used method of communication and collaboration, Jive offers a more efficient and effective way to work. For example, reading and managing long email threads can be time-consuming, whereas in Jive, conversations are organized in a different place, making it easier to follow and participate in discussions.

Another myth about Jive is that people will criticize posts for being too basic or having imperfect grammar. However, Jive is designed to foster an open and collaborative environment where everyone's contributions are valued. Positive responses encourage further participation, while negative responses are not representative of the overall community.

Some people may compare Jive to Facebook and assume it is a time-wasting social platform. However, Jive and Facebook serve different purposes. While Facebook focuses on personal connections and social interactions, Jive is a business collaboration tool that allows for knowledge sharing and professional networking. Jive helps break down the barriers of tribal knowledge within an organization and enables employees to connect with colleagues they may not have otherwise encountered.

Another misconception is that posting on Jive will diminish the knowledge and importance of an individual. In reality, sharing knowledge and experience on Jive increases visibility and demonstrates value to the organization. By answering questions and sharing expertise, individuals can benefit their colleagues and enhance their own professional development.

Concerns about privacy and security on Jive are also addressed. While Jive is a collaborative platform, it offers a security model that allows for limited access to specific groups or individuals. Users have control over who can see their contributions, ensuring that sensitive information remains confidential.

Some may find Jive complex, but familiarity with the platform leads to increased productivity. Jive provides various ways to perform tasks, and formal training and resources are available to help users get started and become comfortable with the platform.

Lastly, Jive can be accessed and interacted with through BlackBerry devices, allowing users to stay connected and engaged even while on the go.

Overall, Jive is a powerful business collaboration tool that enhances communication, collaboration, and knowledge sharing within organizations. It offers several advantages over traditional email and provides a platform for employees to connect, share ideas, and work together more effectively.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
Jive is a social collaboration tool for business that allows people to connect, share ideas, and collaborate across functional areas. It breaks down walls between different departments and facilitates innovation and problem-solving. Jive provides a common platform for employees to find information, connect with colleagues, and contribute to discussions and content. It offers a real-time activity stream that delivers updates on people, groups, documents, and pages that users subscribe to. This stream allows users to quickly skim through relevant information and interact with it, while filtering out irrelevant noise. Jive also provides convenience by offering access through various devices such as iPads and iPhones, as well as integration with Outlook for easy tracking of activity. It can also reduce email volume and improve searchability and inclusiveness of conversations. Overall, Jive enhances collaboration, knowledge sharing, and productivity in the workplace.

Some specific benefits of using Jive include:
- Breaking down silos and connecting people who might never meet, fostering collaboration and innovation.
- Providing a platform for sharing knowledge, exchanging ideas, and solving problems across the entire enterprise.
- Allowing employees to find information and connect with colleagues easily, improving efficiency and effectiveness.
- Offering a comprehensive solution that replaces multiple tools and improves functionality and effectiveness.
- Increasing transparency and empowering employees with information and knowledge.
- Standardizing content and processes, eliminating version control and access challenges.
- Reducing email volume and improving searchability of conversations.
- Leveraging best evidence-based clinical practices in healthcare organizations.
- Creating a place to find "single source of truth" documents and collaborate on them, eliminating version control and access challenges.
- Sharing evidence-based practice instantly and consistently.

These benefits have been realized by various organizations, including Trinity Health, which used Jive to solve healthcare challenges and engage community "gardeners" to extend the reach of Jive groups. Other companies like Philips Electronics have used Jive as a centerpiece for digital transformation strategies. Jive has been successfully implemented in various industries, including technology, manufacturing, and healthcare. It is important to align the Jive strategy with the corporate vision and strategies, involve senior leaders in active participation, recruit advocates, and continuously adjust and improve the platform to keep it fresh and relevant.

question: what all do you know about?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive is a social software platform that offers a better way to work and helps users feel more connected. It combines the features of popular social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter with additional functionalities. Jive allows users to collaborate, communicate, and share information within their organization. It provides tools for creating discussions, asking questions, and sharing knowledge. Jive also offers training resources, such as videos and articles, to help users learn and utilize the platform effectively. Overall, Jive is a comprehensive social collaboration tool that enhances productivity and connectivity in the workplace.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive is a social collaboration platform that goes beyond Facebook and Twitter. It combines features of these platforms with LinkedIn and more. In simple terms, Jive provides a better way to work and helps employees feel more connected. It offers tools for communication, knowledge sharing, and collaboration within organizations.

Jive is influenced by the work of Friedrich Hayek, a renowned economist. Hayek's theories emphasize the importance of decentralized knowledge in a society. Jive aims to tap into the collective knowledge and expertise of employees, enabling better decision-making and problem-solving. It promotes a networked and connected economy, challenging the traditional command and control model of organizations.

Jive offers various types of knowledge within a company. Firstly, there is scientific knowledge that is acquired through formal education. This includes specialized knowledge in fields like law, medicine, and finance. Secondly, there is knowledge of the particular circumstances of time and place, which is learned through experience and on-the-job training. Jive helps facilitate the sharing and acquisition of both types of knowledge.

If you want to learn more about Jive, you can utilize the "Learn" tab on the top menu bar of the platform. It provides resources for searching and self-paced learning. Additionally, there are knowledge base articles and training videos available within the Jive community that can help you ramp up your understanding of the platform.

If you were to go back in time before the launch of your social intranet, it is recommended to focus on additional training for users. This can include instructor-led sessions, text-based resources, and video tutorials. It is also important to simplify the documentation and instructions for less digitally experienced users. Clearly explaining how to navigate and use the platform can improve adoption and engagement.

Jive has been used in various industries, including manufacturing. A case study on how Lexmark uses Jive within their product development teams was published in KMWorld. You can read the article for more insights on knowledge management in manufacturing companies.

Creating and maintaining a Jive knowledge base can involve a significant manual effort. To enhance, review, and verify knowledge created in technical groups, it is suggested to involve the community in the process. Members can suggest content and others can comment on corrections or improvements needed. This ongoing process can help highlight good content and ensure the knowledge base remains accurate and up-to-date.

question: hey what is aws instance management
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 27 June, 2019, here is the answer:
AWS instance management refers to the process of managing and maintaining instances on the Amazon Web Services (AWS) platform. Instances are virtual servers that run in the cloud and provide computing resources for various applications and services.

To effectively manage AWS instances, it is important to gather information about the instance, such as the Jive Software version, Tenant ID, Instance IP Address, and the Shared Services being used. This information can be obtained from the Jive admin console and by contacting the IT department.

The transition to AWS brings several benefits, including enhanced security, availability, and performance. With encryption-at-rest and in-transit, Jive's core application and all services are more secure. High availability across multiple data centers ensures robust disaster recovery. The resilient architecture reduces single points of failure, and continuous innovation and zero downtime upgrades are facilitated.

During the migration to AWS, Jive communities will reside in Amazon's state-of-the-art data centers in regions such as US-East-1 (Virginia, USA) and EU-Central (Frankfurt, Germany). The communities will be scaled to have at least two instances in different data centers, ensuring uptime and performance. Larger communities may have more instances in up to three data centers.

For additional security-oriented information, customers can refer to the Jive AWS Infrastructure and Security Program White Paper. There are also resources available, such as data sheets and webinars, to learn more about the upgrade process, enhanced disaster recovery, and other aspects of the transition.

If there are specific questions or concerns about the upgrade and migration to AWS, customers can contact their Account Manager for assistance.
search_phrase_answer:

Customers can expect enhanced security with encryption-at-rest and in-transit for Jive's core application and all services. High availability spanning multiple data centers will provide robust disaster recovery. Jive cloud and hosted customers will have robust disaster recovery as a standard feature on AWS. The community will be scaled to have at least two instances in two different data centers, with larger communities having more instances in up to three data centers. In the event of an instance or data center failure, the failed instances will automatically get restarted. Performance of every instance is continuously monitored and adjusted as required to ensure performance and availability. Security is a top priority at Jive, and as a customer using Jive Cloud on AWS, you will benefit from a data center and infrastructure built to meet the requirements of the most security-sensitive organizations. For more information, you can refer to the Jive AWS Infrastructure and Security Program white paper. If you have any additional questions about your upgrade, you can contact your Account Manager.

Bunchball offers features such as missions, badges, leaderboards, and points to motivate users to participate and contribute to the community. The platform also provides analytics and reporting capabilities to track the effectiveness of the gamification efforts.

Regarding updates and support for Bunchball, the information is limited. There are mentions of updates for Jive and Bunchball services, but it is unclear how frequently Bunchball specifically is updated for use with Jive. It is recommended to consult with Jive or Bunchball support for the most up-to-date information on updates and support.

In summary, Bunchball is a gamification platform that can be integrated with Jive to create engaging experiences within communities. search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 November, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive Rewards is a feature built into Jive's cloud platform that uses gamification to motivate people to participate in the community. It includes elements such as events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. The goal of Jive Rewards is to promote and accelerate onboarding for new community members, drive desirable behaviors in the community, indicate reputation and achievements, and increase overall usage and engagement. Jive Rewards has default configurations that can be adjusted to meet the specific goals of a community.



To set up Jive Rewards, there are several steps to follow. First, review the goals for the community and determine the desired activities that people should take. For example, if the focus is on providing support, the desired behaviors may include asking and answering questions and marking answers as helpful and correct. Next, plan the gamification "brand" by naming levels and badges and establishing a visual identity. Then, review and adjust the Rewards elements in the management console. This includes configuring events, missions, strategies, quests, levels, and user badges. It is important to ensure that the points assigned to each event align with the community's goals and that the points thresholds for levels are achievable. Additionally, consider enabling user badges to allow users to award each other with badges. Finally, communicate the Rewards program to the community by posting a document explaining what Rewards are and where they can be seen in the community.



Jive Rewards can be used in various ways beyond social business-related activities. For example, it can be used to gamify travel-booking or recognize and reward super-users in different processes and tools. The response to using Jive Rewards to change behavior has been positive, with increased engagement and a desire for more recognition. It is important to measure the impact of the Rewards program and make adjustments as needed to ensure its effectiveness.



Overall, Jive Rewards is a powerful tool for motivating and engaging community members through gamification. It can be customized to fit the specific goals and culture of a community and has the potential to drive desired behaviors and increase participation.

question: how do I use Jive moderation?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 April, 2021, here is the answer:
To use Jive moderation, you can follow these steps:

1. Enable moderation for the desired spaces or content types. This can be done by going to the Admin Console and navigating to the appropriate settings. For example, to enable content moderation, go to System > Moderation > Configure Spam Prevention.

2. Set up moderation rules and thresholds. You can configure various moderation settings, such as link moderation, content moderation, keyword interception, and new user moderation. These settings allow you to control what content gets moderated and how it is handled.

3. Assign moderators. Designate users as moderators for the spaces or content types that require moderation. Moderators will receive notifications and have the ability to review and approve or reject content in the moderation queue.

4. Review and moderate content. Moderators can access the moderation queue to review and take action on content that requires moderation. They can approve or reject content based on the moderation rules and guidelines set up.

5. Monitor and adjust moderation settings. Regularly monitor the effectiveness of your moderation settings and make adjustments as needed. This includes reviewing the moderation queue, analyzing moderation reports, and addressing any issues or concerns raised by users.

It is important to note that moderation settings may vary depending on the version of Jive you are using (Cloud or on-premises) and the specific configuration of your community. It is recommended to refer to the Jive documentation for detailed instructions and best practices on using moderation in your specific environment.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 April, 2021, here is the answer:
To use Jive moderation, you can follow these steps:

1. Enable moderation for the specific space or content type you want to moderate. This can be done in the Admin Console under System > Moderation > Configure Spam Prevention. You can configure different types of moderation, such as content moderation, link moderation, keyword interceptor, and new user moderation.

2. Set up the moderation settings according to your requirements. For example, you can configure the number of abuse reports required before an item is placed into moderation, set a points threshold for content or link moderation, or configure the keyword interceptor to prevent users from creating content with specific keywords or phrases.

3. Assign moderators to the spaces or content types that require moderation. Moderators will receive email notifications when content is placed into the moderation queue and can review and approve or reject the content accordingly.

4. Users can report abuse by flagging content as abuse. This can be done by selecting the "Report Abuse" button on the content. You can configure the number of abuse reports required before an item is placed into moderation.

5. Moderators can access the moderation queue to review and take action on the content that requires moderation. They can accept or reject the content based on the community guidelines and policies.

6. If you want to disable moderation for a specific space, you can go to the advanced settings of that space and uncheck the moderation settings. However, if you are still experiencing moderation even after disabling it, you may need to submit a support case to investigate the issue further.

Please note that the specific steps and options may vary depending on the version of Jive you are using (Cloud or on-premises) and the configuration of your instance. It is recommended to refer to the Jive documentation for detailed instructions on how to use moderation in your specific environment.
answer_similarity_reason: Both answers provide the same steps and information for using Jive moderation, but the new answer provides more detail and additional steps.

question: how do I use jive moderation?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 April, 2021, here is the answer:
To use Jive moderation, you can follow these steps:

1. Enable moderation for the desired spaces or content types. This can be done by going to the Admin Console and navigating to System > Moderation > Configure Spam Prevention. From there, you can configure various moderation settings such as content moderation, link moderation, keyword interceptor, and message governor interceptor.

2. Set up new user moderation if you want to prevent spammers from creating new accounts. This can be done by going to People > Settings > Registration Settings and enabling user self-registration. You can also enable registration moderation to review new user registrations before they are approved.

3. Configure abuse reporting to allow users to flag content as abuse. This can be done by going to Spaces > Settings > Abuse Settings and enabling abuse moderation. You can specify the number of abuse reports required before an item is placed into moderation.

4. Configure user and IP address bans if necessary. This can be done by going to People > Settings > Ban Settings. You can ban users by their Jive account or their IP address to prevent them from logging into Jive.

Please note that moderation settings may vary depending on the version of Jive you are using (Cloud or on-premises) and the specific configuration of your instance. It is recommended to refer to the Jive documentation for detailed instructions on how to configure and use moderation features.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 April, 2021, here is the answer:
Moderation usage in Jive communities can vary depending on the specific needs and culture of the community. In the first extracted part of the document, Dennis Pearce expresses his opinion that moderation should be used sparingly in internal communities to avoid slowing down the workflow. He suggests that it is better to assume the best in people and let their behavior over time determine the need for moderation. Raul Delgado also shares a similar sentiment, stating that moderation would create more headaches than relief in his agency due to the need for dedicated staff and the potential impact on workflow.

In the second extracted part, g BRETT miller suggests that moderation in Jive is similar to moderation in email and should be handled by community managers who monitor the activity and content rather than actively moderating it. He also emphasizes the importance of educating community members on how to report inappropriate content and the effectiveness of peer pressure in maintaining a professional community.

In the third extracted part, Dennis Pearce further emphasizes the importance of behavior-based governance policies rather than technology-based policies. He uses the example of leaving confidential information on a table in the cafeteria to illustrate that the delivery system should not be penalized for the messages created.

In the fourth extracted part, Tammy Triplett shares her agency's approach to moderation, which involves relying on users to "police" the content and use the report abuse feature to remove inappropriate content. She also mentions that permissions are limited to only allow users to post in specific places, which allows for the free flow of information while maintaining control over where content is posted.

In the fifth extracted part, Megan Truett asks about the usage of moderation in Jive communities. The responses from various users indicate that moderation can be enabled for specific content types or spaces, but there may be issues with items not appearing in context or approved items not appearing at all. The users suggest submitting a case to the support team for further investigation.

In the sixth extracted part, Julia Scherbina asks about disabling moderation in a space. The response suggests that moderation can be turned off for a specific space, but if moderation is still occurring despite the settings being disabled, it is recommended to submit a case to the support team for further investigation.

In the seventh extracted part, Jennifer Kelley provides information on abuse reporting and moderation in Jive communities. She mentions that abuse reporting can be enabled to allow users to flag and report objectionable content, and moderation settings can be configured to specify thresholds for moderation. She also suggests having a process in place to handle abuse reports and recommends involving HR in addressing conduct issues.

Overall, the usage of moderation in Jive communities can vary depending on the specific needs and culture of the community. Some users advocate for minimal moderation to avoid slowing down workflow, while others emphasize the importance of behavior-based governance policies and educating community members on reporting inappropriate content. It is recommended to configure moderation settings according to the specific needs of the community and to have processes in place to handle abuse reports.

question: what is jive rewards?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 November, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive Rewards is a set of features built into Jive's cloud platform that enables the use of gamification to motivate people to participate in the community. It includes elements such as events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. The default configurations of Jive Rewards allow it to work right out of the box, with users earning points, missions, and badges immediately. However, it is recommended to review the configuration settings before launching to ensure that rewards are given for activities that align with the community's specific goals.

Gamification, which is the application of game design techniques to non-game scenarios, has several benefits for a community. It helps promote and accelerate onboarding for new members, drives desirable behaviors within the community, indicates reputation and achievements, and increases overall usage and engagement. Jive Rewards can be personalized and adjusted to fit the community's goals and culture.

To learn more about Jive Rewards, you can refer to the following resources:
- [Why use Rewards?](#jive_content_id_Why_use_Rewards)
- [Elements of Jive Rewards](#jive_content_id_Elements_of_Jive_Rewards)

search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 7 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 November, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive Rewards is a set of features built into Jive's cloud platform that enables you to use gamification to motivate people to participate in the community. It includes elements such as events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. Gamification is the application of game design techniques or game mechanics to work or other non-game scenarios to drive desired behaviors. It can be seen in various aspects of daily life, such as store loyalty/rewards cards, badges or insignia that indicate rank or status, or the prompts and rewards from fitness tracking apps like Fitbit or Jawbone.

Using gamification in your community can have several benefits. It can help promote and accelerate onboarding for new community members, drive desirable behaviors in the community (e.g., asking and answering questions, marking answers as helpful and correct), indicate reputation and achievements within the site, and drive overall usage and engagement.

Jive Rewards has default configurations that allow it to work right out of the box, with people earning points, missions, and badges immediately. However, it is recommended to review the configuration settings before launching to ensure that rewards are being given for activities that align with your community's specific goals.

To set up Jive Rewards, you can follow these steps:
1. Review the goals for your community and determine the activities that align with those goals.
2. Plan your gamification "brand" by naming levels and badges and establishing a visual identity.
3. Adjust the rewards elements, such as events, strategies, missions, quests, and levels, to match your community's goals.
4. Consider enabling user badges if you want users to be able to award each other with badges.
5. Communicate the rewards program to your community members, explaining what rewards are, where they can see rewards elements, and any guidelines or rules.

It is important to note that when setting up Jive Rewards, you should be cautious not to switch off too many missions or strategies, as event points need to flow through a mission and strategy to be counted towards a level. Additionally, there are other resources available, such as a Rewards workbook, documentation, webinars, and blog posts, that can provide more information and best practices for implementing gamification in your community.

If you need further assistance or guidance in implementing a gamification program for your community, you can reach out to your Account Manager or Customer Success Manager to discuss whether engaging with the Professional Services team is the right option for you.

question: What is DES?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013). DES allows users to access user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API that can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides access directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface that allows users to access analytics information in CSV format through a configurable web interface. Once the CSV is obtained, it can be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. For example, DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is important to compare it only against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

DES has certain requirements, including a Jive community that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. There are also limitations to DES, such as a maximum of 10,000 rows returned in a CSV and a maximum file size of 180 MB for downloading historical CSVs.

For more information and documentation on DES, users can refer to the provided links in the extracted parts of the document.

question: Security Questions
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To add a custom security question on the Forgot Username/Password link in Jive, it is unclear from the provided information whether there is a specific Jive property or setting available for this purpose. It is recommended to consult the Jive documentation or contact Jive Support for more information on how to add custom security questions for authentication on the Forgot Username/Password link.

Regarding security questions in general, it is important for organizations to consider various risks and requirements when implementing them. Different departments within an organization may have different perspectives on security risks. Legal departments may focus on personal data protection and eDiscovery requirements, while HR departments may consider the impact on organizational hierarchy and performance evaluations. Audit departments may also need to address eDiscovery concerns. It is crucial for organizations to settle on a position that aligns with their risk profile, country, and context. It is also important to involve relevant stakeholders, such as legal, HR, and audit, in the decision-making process.

When implementing social collaboration tools like Jive, it is not the responsibility of the social evangelist to raise all potential risks or find answers for them. Instead, the social evangelist should inform other departments about the tools being used, provide access for experimentation, and encourage them to identify any issues that need to be addressed. It is then the responsibility of each department to develop recommendations and implement solutions for the identified risks. question: What is DES API?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Jive Data Export Service (DES) is a service that allows users to export analytics data from their Jive community. It was introduced in the Jive Cloud Fall (2013) release and Jive 7. DES provides access to user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API, which can be used to access the data programmatically, and the DES Explorer, which provides access to the data through a user-friendly web interface.

To access the DES, users need a Jive community (Cloud, Hosted, or On-Premise) that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. The DES Explorer can be accessed directly from the community by logging in and going to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, users can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data in CSV format.

It's important to note that the data retrieved from the DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics or Google Analytics, due to differences in data collection methods and time spans. When using data from the DES, it's recommended to compare it only with data from the DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

The DES API has new endpoints for AWS DES, which are different depending on whether the customer is in the US or EU. The endpoints for US customers are "https://api-aws.jivesoftware.com", and for EU customers, they are "https://api-eu-aws.jivesoftware.com". Authentication for the DES API is done using a client ID and secret.

Overall, the DES API and DES Explorer provide users with powerful tools to access and export analytics data from their Jive community, allowing for deeper analysis and insights into user activity.

DES allows you to access user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). It is important to note that the data you retrieve from DES may not match up with Cloud Analytics, CMR, or other analytics platforms like Google Analytics or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. The DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of your community. When using data from DES, it is important to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, you can log in to your community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, you can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

The DES API has new endpoints for AWS DES, but they have not been announced yet due to an ongoing issue. Once the issue is fixed, more information will be provided. It is important to note that the new AWS DES API endpoints may require updating the URL endpoints for API scripts and integrations.

For more information on DES and how to use it, you can refer to the Jive documentation on Using the V2 Jive Data Export Service (Analytics) and Analytics - Developer Resources.

You can access the sandbox by following the instructions provided in the document: "How to Access the *NEW* Jive Developer Sandbox" (https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-172438). The sandbox provides examples and test results against Jive's sandbox environment (https://sandbox.jiveon.com).

Additionally, you can refer to the Jive Developers landing page (https://developer.jivesoftware.com/) and the API Documentation for more information on testing and integrating with Jive. The Jive Developers community (https://thrive.ignitetech.com/community/customers/developer/activity) is also a valuable resource for developers, where you can find discussions and support related to Jive development.

If you are developing plugins like editor extensions, it is recommended to test them in an on-premise Jive instance. This allows you to have more control over the testing environment and ensure compatibility with your specific Jive deployment.

question: Connect JMX on webapp?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 12 February, 2018, here is the answer:
To connect JMX on a webapp, you need to follow these steps:

1. Set up your IDE for remote debugging. In IntelliJ IDEA, you can create a configuration for Tomcat by selecting Run -> Edit Configurations, clicking Add New Configuration, selecting Remote, and setting the Port to 8787. In Eclipse, you can create a Remote Java Application configuration by selecting Debug Configurations, choosing Remote Java Application, and specifying the port as 8787.

2. Configure your web application to enable remote debugging. In the web.xml file of your application, you need to add the following configuration for the JspServlet:

\`\`\`

jsp
org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServlet

fork
false


xpoweredBy
false


compilerSourceVM
1.8


compilerTargetVM
1.8

3

\`\`\`

3. Start your web application with remote debugging enabled. If you are using Maven, you can run your application with the following command: \`mvn -Dcargo.wait=true -P int integration-test\`. In IntelliJ IDEA, select the Runtime Configuration you created and click Run -> Debug. In Eclipse, select the Debug Configuration you created and click Debug.

4. Your IDE will connect to the Tomcat process and display the Debug view. You can now debug your web application remotely.

Please note that these instructions assume you are using Tomcat as your web server. If you are using a different web server, the steps may vary slightly.

To connect JMX on a webapp, you can follow the steps below:

Step 1: Set Up Your IDE
1. Configure Remote Debugging in IDEA:
- Select Run -> Edit Configurations
- Click Add New Configuration
- Select Remote
- Name the Configuration
- Set the Port to 8787
- Uncheck Make in the Before Launch section
- Uncheck Display settings before launching
- Click Apply

2. Configure Remote Debugging for Eclipse:
- Drop down the Debug button, and choose the Debug Configurations... item
- Select Remote Java Application in the Configurations list and click the New Configuration button.
- Name the configuration.
- Specify the project to debug (web).
- Specify the port (8787).
- Click Apply.
- Click Debug.

Step 2: Remotely Debug Tomcat
- Be sure you have a remote configuration for Tomcat to port 8787. Repeat the steps above for creating a Remote Debugger.
- Run this with Maven:
mvn -Dcargo.wait=true -P int integration-test
- In IDEA, select the Runtime Configuration you created from the drop down in the tool bar.
- Run -> Debug.
- IDEA will connect to the Tomcat process and display the Debug view.

Debugging Unit Tests
- Debugging unit tests is very simple with Maven and Surefire. All you have to do is specify the maven.surefire.debug system property on the command line:
mvn -Dmaven.surefire.debug test
- To specify a specific test use:
mvn -Dmaven.surefire.debug -Dtest= test

question: What is expiry time in Jive ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The expiry time in Jive refers to the ability to set expiration dates for content using content metadata. This feature allows authors to receive emails in advance of the expiration date, giving them the opportunity to update the content and prevent it from expiring. The general idea is to have a lightweight app or add-on that can be used in Jive 6.0.1+ and Jive 7. The estimated development time for this customization is 3-4 weeks. The cost of developing the app/add-on and running the service is around $20K, which can be split between the customers who back the project. The more backers there are, the lower the cost per customer. The goal is to convince Jive to include this functionality in a future version if it proves to be useful and widely used.

In terms of session expiration and login, Jive has a system property called "login.rememberme.disabled" that can be set to true to force users to reauthenticate every time their session expires. The session expiration time is controlled by the "auth.lifetime" property, which defaults to 30 minutes. However, when using Single Sign-On (SSO), the process is more complicated. When a user logs in via SSO, they will have a session created in Jive that is valid for the specified auth.lifetime. Once that period expires, Jive will send the user back to the SSO provider to log in again. The SAML settings include a Maximum Authentication Age to prevent users from staying logged in too long. If the SSO server responds with a "valid" statement that is older than the Maximum Authentication Age, the response is rejected on the Jive side, and the user receives a login error. To work around this issue, the user can visit the SSO side, log out manually, and then log back in to refresh the authentication statement.

Regarding password expiration, Jive does not have built-in functionality for expiring passwords for non-federated users. However, it is possible to customize and develop this feature. One option is to set a password expiration period and redirect users to a page to reset their password when it expires. Another option is to use Active Directory with multiple domain access to handle different user setups.

For OAuth2 tokens, Jive provides the ability to revoke tokens and set expiration date/time intervals for both access and refresh tokens in the UI. Tokens can be revoked using the OAuth Client Management feature.

In terms of the Jive for Mobile app, users may experience OAuth Token Expired errors if they don't use the app frequently. In this case, they can manually log in again by entering the correct community URL. It is not currently possible to configure the app to automatically try logging in again if the OAuth Token has expired.

Lastly, if you need to update the copyright date in Jive, you can make arrangements to advance the date to the desired year. This can be done by modifying the copyright message at the bottom of each Jive page.

question: Is community and instance different terms in Jive ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
Yes, community and instance are different terms in Jive. In Jive, a community refers to a group of people working together to solve business problems. It is a collaborative space where users can find and network with colleagues, share information, and engage in discussions. On the other hand, an instance in Jive refers to a specific installation or deployment of the Jive software. Each instance serves a specific audience or purpose and may have different levels of security and functionality. Instances can be tailored to meet the needs of different user groups or departments within an organization. Therefore, while both terms are related to collaboration and communication, they have distinct meanings in the context of Jive.
search_phrase: Difference between community and instance in Jive
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
The difference between community and instance in Jive can be understood as follows:

In Jive, a community refers to a group or space where users can collaborate, share information, and engage in discussions. It is a platform for communication and knowledge sharing within a specific group or topic. Communities can be created for different purposes, such as for classes, teams, or specific software products. They serve as knowledge repositories and allow participants to continue conversations even after a class or event has ended. Communities can be role-based or specific to a certain product or team.

On the other hand, an instance in Jive refers to a separate installation or deployment of the Jive software. Each instance serves a specific audience or purpose and has its own set of features, security settings, and customization options. Instances can be used for different purposes, such as customer service, sales, or internal collaboration. They can also be tailored to meet the needs of different brands or departments within an organization.

Instances in Jive can have varying levels of security and access controls to ensure that the right information is shared with the right audience. For example, some instances may require authentication or have IP whitelists to restrict access. Instances can also be used to manage content overlaps and ensure that content is consistent across different communities.

The main difference between a community and an instance in Jive is that a community refers to a specific group or space within an instance where users collaborate, while an instance refers to the overall installation or deployment of the Jive software that serves a specific audience or purpose. Communities exist within instances and provide a platform for users to engage and share information.

question: How to set kubectl to access MAKO?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the kubectl binary from the official Kubernetes website. You can find the download link [here](http://maven.apache.org/download.html).

2. Once the binary is downloaded, unpack it on your system. If you are using a Mac, you can explode the zip file to /usr/local. If you are using Windows, extract the downloaded Maven zip file to the root of the C: drive, which will create a maven-2.2.1 folder.

3. Set your environment path. For Mac, add a M2_HOME environment variable to your ~/.bash_profile and point it to your download, e.g.:
\`\`\`
export M2_HOME=/usr/local/apache-maven-2.2.1
\`\`\`
Also, add the $M2_HOME/bin directory to your path, before /usr/bin.

For Windows, adjust the System Path Variable by appending a semi-colon and the location of the maven\bin directory, for example, C:\maven-2.2.1\bin.

4. Test your installation by running the command \`mvn --version\` in the terminal. You should see the Apache Maven version and Java version information.

These steps should help you set up kubectl to access MAKO.
search_phrase: Set up kubectl access for MAKO
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set up kubectl access for MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Launch the Keychain Access app on your Mac.
2. In the top menu, select Keychain Access > Certificate Assistant > Request a Certificate From a Certificate Authority.
3. In the User Email Address field, enter your company email address.
4. In the Common Name field, enter your company name or personal name.
5. Select Save to disk.
6. Clear the Let me specify key pair information check box.
7. Click Continue and save the request.
8. Go back to the Developer Portal, select Choose, and then select the certificate request.
9. Select Continue.
10. Download the push certificate and double-click the certificate to import it into Keychain Access.

Please note that these instructions assume you have the necessary permissions and access to the required tools and resources. If you encounter any issues or errors during the process, it is recommended to consult the official documentation or seek assistance from your system administrator or IT support team.
